leftPanel.title: Four Main Categories
paragraphs: Traditional Banks: For-profit institutions with physical branches, extensive ATM networks, and wide service offerings.
Credit Unions: Member-owned cooperatives offering lower fees and better rates, with membership requirements.
Online Banks: Digital-only with no branches, typically offering highest APYs and lowest fees.
Investment Platforms: Brokerage firms and robo-advisors specializing in growing wealth through investments.

leftPanel.title: Fees Can Add Up Quickly
paragraphs: Hidden fees are one of the biggest ways financial institutions make money from customers. Know what you're paying for.
Monthly Maintenance: $5-15/month unless you meet minimum requirements.
Overdraft Fees: $25-35 per transaction when you spend more than your balance.
ATM Fees: $2-5 per transaction at out-of-network ATMs.

highlightBox.text: � These fees can total $200+ per year. Many online banks and credit unions offer fee-free accounts.

layoutData.title: What Access Do You Need?
paragraphs: Your lifestyle and banking habits should influence which provider you choose. Consider how you'll access your money and what services matter to you.
bulletPoints: Branch Locations: Important if you prefer in-person service or deposit cash frequently
ATM Network: Larger networks mean fewer fees; some banks reimburse ATM fees
Mobile Banking: Quality apps with mobile deposit, transfers, bill pay, budgeting tools
Customer Service: 24/7 phone support, chat, response times for issues
Loans & Credit: Auto loans, mortgages, credit cards, personal loans
Investment Options: Some banks offer brokerage services; others don't

leftPanel.title: Protecting Your Money
paragraphs: Security should be a top priority when choosing any financial provider. Look for both insurance protection and digital security measures.
FDIC Insurance: Protects bank deposits up to $250,000 per depositor.
NCUA Insurance: Same protection for credit union deposits.
SIPC Protection: Protects brokerage accounts up to $500,000.
Also look for: Two-factor authentication, fraud monitoring, and zero-liability protection.

layoutData.title: Long-Term Financial Impact
paragraphs: The financial service provider you choose affects your money every single day. Over years, these differences compound into significant amounts.
bulletPoints: Fee Savings: $200/year in avoided fees = $10,000 over 50 years (invested)
Interest Earned: Higher APY on savings accelerates emergency fund and goals
Loan Costs: 1% lower rate on car loan = $700+ saved over 5 years
Investment Fees: 0.5% less in fees = tens of thousands more at retirement
Convenience: Easy access reduces financial friction and stress
Relationships: Good provider relationships help when you need loans or assistance

leftPanel.title: Different Situations, Different Needs
paragraphs: College Student: Online bank with no fees, high APY savings, good mobile app.
Someone Saving for a Purchase: Highest APY savings account, possibly a CD for fixed goals.
Young Professional Investing: Robo-advisor or low-cost brokerage with retirement accounts.
Small Business Owner: Bank with business services, merchant processing, business loans.

scenario.name: Sophia: First Bank Account Decision in {{STATE_NAME}}
paragraphs: Sophia is starting college and needs her first bank account. She's comparing two options:
Option A (Online Bank): No monthly fees, no minimum balance, 1.5% APY on savings, excellent mobile app.
Option B (Local Credit Union): Personalized service, local branches, 0.8% APY on savings, $5 monthly fee waived with $300 minimum.
Which should she choose? It depends on her priorities‚Äîhigher interest and no fees vs. in-person service.
